title: Quiz 8: Chronic Airborne & CNS Infections
description: Critical quiz on Tuberculosis (TB), Leprosy, and Meningococcal Meningitis.

questions.question: What is the primary method used to diagnose infectious Pulmonary Tuberculosis (PTB)?
questions.explanation: Examining three early-morning sputum specimens for Acid Fast Bacilli (AFB) is the standard for TB diagnosis.
questions.hint: Think of the bacilli found in phlegm.

questions.question: Which of the following are EARLY signs and symptoms of Tuberculosis? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Cough, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue are early signs. Haemoptysis usually occurs in later stages.

questions.question: What does the WHO treatment strategy 'DOTS' stand for?
questions.explanation: DOTS ensures the patient is supervised during medication intake to ensure compliance and prevent drug resistance.

questions.question: Match the Leprosy type with its characteristic:
questions.explanation: Pauci means few; Multi means many. This refers to the concentration of bacilli in the skin.

questions.question: In Leprosy, what is the main cause of the characteristic hand and foot deformities (e.g., claw hand)?
questions.explanation: Mycobacterium leprae damages peripheral nerves, leading to sensory loss (burns/wounds) and motor paralysis (deformities).
questions.hint: The bacteria attacks the schwann cells of nerves.

questions.question: The causative agent of epidemic meningitis is ___BLANK___, and the definitive diagnostic procedure is a ___BLANK___ puncture.
questions.explanation: Neisseria causes the disease; a lumbar puncture is needed to sample the CSF.
questions.hint: Think of the 'coccus' and the spinal tap.

questions.question: Arrange the clinical priorities when managing a suspected case of Meningococcal Meningitis:

items.text: Stat IM dose of Crystalline Penicillin
Notification of the District Medical Officer

questions.explanation: Diagnosis must be confirmed, antibiotics started immediately, and the patient isolated and reported to prevent an epidemic.

questions.question: Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs are physical indicators used to suspect meningitis.
questions.explanation: These signs test for meningeal irritation (neck rigidity and leg pain upon hip flexion).
questions.hint: They are core neurological physical exams.

questions.question: Review the TB drug table below. Which drug is NOT given to small children because it can impair vision?
questions.explanation: Ethambutol can cause optic neuritis (vision loss). Since small children cannot report vision changes, it is avoided.

questions.question: Which vaccine given at birth provides partial protection against Tuberculosis and some immunity against Leprosy?
questions.explanation: The BCG vaccine is a foundational part of childhood immunization in endemic countries.
questions.hint: Check the baby's left arm for the scar.
